questionListItems.title: What are the considerations that IPCs need to take when issuing tax-deduction receipts (TDRs) to donors on qualifying donations received?

answer.body: Please ensure that the purpose of the donations received by the IPC is exclusively beneficial to the community in Singapore as a whole and is not confined to sectional interests or groups of persons based on race, belief or religion. The purpose of donations must also be in line with the charitable objects under the IPC’s governing instruments.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Can IPCs receive donations from foreign corporate or individual donors?

answer.body: The Charities Act/Regulations does not prohibit charities with IPC status from receiving funding or donations from foreign individuals and organisations. Nevertheless, the IPC may wish to conduct some form of due diligence on the incoming donation (e.g. whether any conditions imposed on the donation; donation is in line with the Charity/IPC’s objects; donor is a bona-fide organisation etc.), before accepting such donations.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Can IPCs conduct fund-raising appeals or make donations for foreign charitable causes?

answer.body:
In accordance to the Charities (Institution of a Public Character) Regulations, the activities of an Institution of a Public Character (IPC) must be exclusively beneficial to the community in Singapore. Hence, an IPC has to conduct activities which are beneficial to the Singapore community.

 

Unless ministerial waiver is granted to IPCs to carry out overseas work

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: How and when do IPCs need to submit the Annual Return of Tax-Deduction Donations to IRAS? Do IPCs still need to submit an Annual Returns on TDD to the Office of COC?

answer.body:
IPCs are required to submit its Annual Return for Tax Deductible Donations (TDD) to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) for the calendar year by 31 January of the following year. The information would include a list of donors with the NRIC, FIN or UEN of each donor (individual or corporate). Tax deductions will be granted to qualifying donations based on the list submitted by the IPCs.

 

With effect from calendar year 2019, if the IPC submits the Annual Return of Tax Deductible Donations (TDD) to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) received for the calendar year via ipcLink; or the Offline Validation Programme (OVP) (before 2 Jan 2024); or via the Donation (Corppass) API (after 2 Jan 2024), the IPC do not need to submit the Annual Return for TDD to the Commissioner of Charities (COC) or Sector Administrator (SA).

 

However, if the IPC receives some TDD via the payroll deduction mode which are not reported via ipcLink or the OVP or Donation (Corppass) API, apart from the Annual Return for TDD submitted to IRAS, the IPC must continue to submit its Annual Return for TDD to the COC or SA before 31 January each year.

 

To submit the Annual Returns of TDD via the Charity Portal (http://www.charities.gov.sg), please click on “Annual Return for Tax Deductible Donations (for Payroll Deductions Only)” on the left menu to complete and submit the form.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Why must an IPC post its key financial and non-financial information online?

answer.body: All IPCs are subjected to more stringent regulations, one of which is to post their key financial and non-financial information online so as to be transparent and accountable to the public and the wider community. It can post information at its own website, or at the Charity Portal.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Can an IPC issue tax deduction receipt (TDR) to a third-party fundraiser, who then gives the TDR to the donors?

answer.body: Only IPCs are allowed to issue TDRs and they should be issuing them to the donors directly. For proper accountability, the IPC should be collecting all donations and then pay the fund-raiser any fees that were agreed upon previously in a written contract. Should the fund-raiser then wish to donate a portion of this fee back to the IPC, a TDR can then be issued.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Where can IPCs find the IPCLink software?

answer.body:
From 2 Jan 2024, the Donation (Corppass) API will be the only mode to submit tax-deductible donations to IRAS. User(s) will need to use DMS Lite or any other commercially available DMS that supports API submissions to IRAS in order to make submissions for YA2024.

 

For more information, please contact data_mgmt@iras.gov.sg.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: A donor has recently made a donation to an IPC. What documents do I need to submit to IRAS in order to qualify for the tax deduction?

answer.body: Donors are not required to submit any tax deduction receipt for verification purposes. IPCs are obliged to submit an Annual Tax-Deduction Donation Returns to IRAS for the calendar year by 31 January of the following year. The information would include a list of donors with the NRIC, FIN or UEN of each donor (individual or corporate). Tax deductions will be granted to qualifying donations based on the list submitted by the IPCs. Hence, qualifying donations will be automatically reflected in donor’s tax assessment for the year based on the information provided by the IPC.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Will the donation received through an auction held by an IPC qualify donors for tax deduction?

answer.body: Where the donor receives a benefit in return for the donation made (in this case the auctioned items), the tax deduction is only granted on the difference between the donation and cost of benefit. In other words, the tax deduction is granted to buyers for the difference in the purchase price and the market value of the auctioned items. Please refer to the e-Tax guide on Tax treatment on donation with benefits (Donations made on or after 19 March 2021), issued by IRAS, available on the IRAS) website for more information.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Do cryptocurrencies (e.g. Bitcoins) and NFT donations qualify for 250% tax deductions?

answer.body:
According to the Inland Revenue Authority Singapore (IRAS), only outright cash donations that do not give material benefit to the donor are tax-deductible. Donations with benefits in return will be treated as pure donations if the benefits are treated as having no commercial value. For more information on the various types of tax deductible and non-tax deductible donations, please visit the IRAS website.

 

As cryptocurrencies and NFT donations are not regarded as cash donations, please note that the 250% tax deductions will not be applicable.

topics.title: Institution of a Public Character (IPC) Status

questionListItems.title: Does the change in registered name constitute an amendment to the governing instrument?

answer.body: Yes. For more information on amending governing instruments, please visit the Charity Portal >> “Managing Your Charity >> “Duties and Responsibilities of the Governing Board >> “amending Your Governing Instruments”.

questionListItems.title: What are the procedures that a charity/IPC need to take note if there are any changes in the charity/IPC’s profile from time to time?

answer.body:
The charity should notify the COC/SA within 7 days if there are any changes in:

 

a)     Composition of the governing board;

b)     Personal details of governing board members;

c)     Address of each immovable property;

d)     Appointment or removal of trustees;

e)     Changes in charity’s governing instruments; and

f)      Any other organisational details such as key officers and contact information.

 

**If the charity is incorporated as a Society or CLG, certain updates such as addition and removal of governing board members, change of the charity’s name or registered address will have to be updated through lodgement with the Registry of Societies (via iROSES) or the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (via BizFile) respectively before the updates are filed on the Charity Portal. The data on the changes would be ported over in two working days and should be reflected under the respective modules of the “Update Charity Profile”, where the changes are effected.

questionListItems.title: What are the steps to submit amendments to the governing instrument (i.e. Constitution) of a society charity?

answer.body:
The steps to amending the governing instrument of a charity incorporated as a society is listed as follows:

 

  1. Submit the proposed amendments to the COC/SA via the Charity Portal (http://www.charities.gov.sg). Select “Update Charity Profile” >> “Amendments to Governing Instrument”. Please complete and submit the proposed amendments to Governing Instrument using the template attached within Step 1 of the form. Please upload the proposed amendments to the governing instruments, a copy of the charity’s latest Constitution prior to incorporating the amendments and other relevant supporting documents within Step 1 of the form.

  2. The COC/SA will review and may propose changes or additions.

  3. Upon receipt of the Letter of No Objection from COC/SA, please proceed to seek approval of all amendments at General Meeting.

  4. Submit the changes to ROS with the proposed amendments and COC/SA’s Letter of No Objection.

  5. Upon approval from ROS, please proceed to submit the charity profile update with the Minutes of Meeting where the amendments were approved, certified true copy of the amended governing instrument and ROS’s notification of approval by completing Step 2 of the “Amendments to Governing Instrument” via the Charity Portal.

questionListItems.title: What are the steps to submit amendments to the governing instrument (i.e. M&AA/Constitution) of a CLG charity?

answer.body:
The steps to amending the governing instrument of a charity incorporated as a CLG is as follows:

 

  1. Submit the proposed amendments to the COC/SA via the Charity Portal. Select “Update Charity Profile” >> “Amendments to Governing Instrument”. Please complete and submit the proposed amendments to Governing Instrument using the template attached within Step 1 of the form. Please upload the proposed amendments to the governing instruments, a copy of the charity’s latest Constitution prior to incorporating the amendments and other relevant supporting documents within Step 1 of the form.

  2. The COC/SA will review and may propose changes or additions.

  3. Upon receipt of the Letter of No Objection from COC/SA, please proceed to seek approval of all amendments at General Meeting.

  4. Lodge the amendments with ACRA.

  5. Proceed to submit a charity profile update with the certified true copy of the revised governing instruments Minutes of Meeting where the amendments were approved and ACRA’s notification of lodgement. to complete Step 2 of the “Amendments to Governing Instrument” via the Charity Portal.

questionListItems.title: What are the steps to amend the governing instrument (i.e. trust deed) of a charitable trust?

answer.body:
The steps to amending the governing instrument of a charitable trust is listed as follows:

 

  1. Submit the proposed amendments to the COC/SA via the Charity Portal. Select “Update Charity Profile” >> “Amendments to Governing Instrument”. Please complete and submit the proposed amendments to Governing Instrument using the template attached within Step 1 of the form. Please upload the proposed amendments to the governing instruments, a copy of the charity’s latest Constitution prior to incorporating the amendments and other relevant supporting documents within Step 1 of the form.

  2. The COC/SA will review and may propose changes or additions.

  3. Upon receipt of the Letter of No Objection from COC/SA, please proceed to seek approval of all amendments at General Meeting as well as any other relevant authority’s approval, in accordance with the charity’s governing instrument.

  4. Submit the charity profile update with the Minutes of Meeting where the amendments were approved and a true copy of the amended trust deed and approval from the relevant authority (if applicable) by completing Step 2 of the “Amendments to Governing Instrument” via the Charity Portal.
